comment: This is a delicious pour. Notes of oak and silky vanilla on the nose. The mouthfeel is coating and smooth with lots of creamy chocolate and vanilla. The finish is a tad short but there is very little heat for the proof. One of the best bourbons of 2017. Excellent edition to the Parker's Heritage lineup.
It was ok,i wasn't a huge fan though. Nice on the nose. Palate and finish were just ok

So I grabbed a pour of this for 20 bones. Beautiful nose with very prevalent notes of vanilla. Great viscosity rich oaky tones while holding the vanilla. Delving in deeper I found honey covered crostini with a warm peppery finish. I don't think I'll buy it again, but I'm thrilled I got to taste it.
Drinks below its proof. Hits your typical bourbon notes; nothing to complain about but nothing to make it stand out either. Unfortunate price.
Lovely sweet complex nose, hot thin complex body, sweet and spicy. Worth a try, not pappy, but very bold, complex and satisfying. Similar to bookers, but a bit more sugar Carmel

Spice, fresh linens, clover honey on the nose. Deep flavor on the palate, pleasantly oaky, sweet, baking spice, a hint of turpentine. The whole flavor profile lingers. A great Kentucky hug. Worthy of the PHC line. 5/12/18
Have had this twice. Beautiful finish and creamy mouthfeel. wish I could find affordable pricing but will enjoy it at a few establishments where I can get it locally.
a bit syrupy, but deep. hot.
Light spicy, smooth heat. Lovely and balanced.

Golden amber in color. Intense spicy oak on the nose. Manageable at cask strength but water really opens up the nose. More toffee and caramel and sweet fruit. Tons of flavor on the palate, all things expected from a cask strength Heaven Hill product. Very Elijah Craig-ish in nature. The finish is long lasting with some white pepper and more bitter oak, neither of which are a bad thing! Highly recommended
Holy crap, that’s good! Wonderfully smooth for being 120+. Hard to pin down flavors, much going on here. The heat hangs on, be warned.
Forward heat. Lots of spice. Vanillas are pushed back. Burnt brown sugar. Slightly Buttery mouthfeel.
Amazing.  Despite its high proof, it doesn’t burn out your palate.  Rich, creamy, mouthfeel.  Buttery taste.  Can’t wait to find a bottle.
Wow, pure liquid gold. You can tell it's high proof but it doesn't feel like it lacks balance. Just the tiniest taste. I love it.
Favorite whiskey of 2017. Fantastic example of the Heaven Hill flavor profile. Deatsville is where it’s at!
Rich, Robust, and Full bodied. Reminded me of most George Stagg offerings.
Single best bourbon I have ever had. Smooth as silk and rich with flavor. Its like sipping something from a fine candy store, not a bar.

Now this is what bourbon should taste like! Probably one of my favorite drams. Reminds me of Elijah Craig Barrel Proof, but bumped up a notch. Approachable without water, but even just a few drops really open up the nose and show what an impressive job Heaven Hill has done.
Holy Heatwave!  Intense spiciness, but oh so good.  Chocolate middle, vanilla beginning, and a spicy black pepper oak finish.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Really enjoyed this pour.

Nose- creamy vanilla, orange soda, black pepper, rich oak throughout, tobacco 

Palate- smoke and charred oak, spices, roasted nuts, orange, and corn on the cob

Finish- Spicy undertones with hints of oak and tobacco 

Bold and in your face, and anything but sweet. This is a fantastic bourbon that hides its proof on both the nose and finish. Nicely balanced and just what you would expect from an 11 year single barrel bourbon from Parkers.
Deep deep flavor but a little burn
Virtually no alcohol burn on the nose which is amazing for the proof. Pepper and spices on the nose with a little smoke and caramel. Lots of spicy on the taste but super smooth going down.
This is fantastic! Blows the orange curaçao one out of the water. If you see a bottle, buy it for me.
🔥🔥🔥 YFY and very hot.  So damn good.  Parker’s never fails me.

The nose is full of baking spices, oak, vanilla, sweet apples and a touch of port. The palate is very dry and heavy on oak, with black pepper, cinnamon, vanilla and caramel that slowly builds up as the pepper fades. The finish is long, warm and spicy with a mouthful of oak, fading pepper and vanilla and cinnamon.
